review_title: High turnover and poor work-life balance
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Paul, MN
pros: It was cool to meet some of the young professionals and learn how Genesys Works benefited them. There are a lot of good people at the organization who care about the mission. The pay and benefits were good by nonprofit standards.
cons: Genesys Works Twin Cities has an ongoing high turnover problem. When I was there, the majority of directors had been with the organization for less than a year. This results in a loss of institutional knowledge and a difficult situation for new employees. The organization has a culture of overwork. Routinely working on evenings and weekends is normalized. A lot of time and resources go into putting on elaborate events that do not help advance the organization's mission, in my opinion.

review_title: Great at a glance, but troublesome up close. Toxic culture, disturbing leadership, no real strategy.
pros: - Dedicated, hard-working, student-focused Program Coordinators
cons:
- Toxic culture (siloed teams, limited to no collaboration)
- Poor leadership at local and national levels (uninformed decision-making and driven by their self-interest)
- No accountability for poor performance or disrespectful behavior
- Lack of strategy to achieve organizational goals
- Non-existent change management
- Inequitable pay for people of color

pros: Teaches essential IT experience and what to expect in a professional work environment
cons: the pay could be more

review_title: Difficult to see a path forward for this organization
pros:
The high school students served by Genesys Works are amazing, motivated, impressive young people and it's inspiring to see them flourish during the program.

Many of the staff members (especially those directly serving students) are equally motivated and impressive; they are passionate about economic justice and will work tirelessly to help their students have success in college, careers, and life, often despite the obstacles that the organization puts in their way.
cons:
The fundamental challenge for Genesys Works is not knowing its purpose. There is no alignment about the definition of a successful outcome for a student, and as a result there is no coherent strategy or program model to drive to that outcome. The result is harm to students, frustrated staff, and disappointed corporate partners. 

The culture, especially at the top, is the most toxic, dysfunctional, and disappointing that I have ever experienced. Because there is no clear strategy or consistent model, there is no alignment around success metrics and therefore no accountability. Executive Directors spend more time convincing their boards that they are doing a good job, rather than just doing a good job. It's a culture of fear in which leaders are more concerned about making themselves look good rather than surfacing and solving real challenges that would lead to improvements in both the culture and the outcomes for students. Leaders seem more interested in maintaining the status quo than embracing new ideas, despite a history of serving fewer students year over year that indicates change is needed. Everyone seems to be channeling all of their energy into fighting to protect something that is really not worth protecting. 

The structure is also a contributing factor to the challenges at Geneys Works. The federated model is confusing and creates a major obstacle to positive change because it's very unclear where and how decisions are made, and who ultimately holds leaders accountable. Great initiatives and innovations have been shut down because of push back and complaints from leaders not willing to do the work or embrace change, and a lack of authority or energy from the CEO in pushing in through anyway because it's best for the organization.

review_title: The mission is in the right place but missing leadership
pros: GW has some of the best employees/coworkers/friends I could have imagined out of working somewhere. The mission and the students are the reason why so many employees put up with the bad leadership and being overworked. The young professionals are incredible and watching their growth is really impactful.
cons: The national leadership is why the turnover is so high. They make decisions that don't align to the values of the local sites and have a VERY top down approach without considering that there is zero capacity at the local sites. Local site management are responsible for multiple jobs/functions (especially at smaller sites) and are not compensated adequately. Instead, they are just asked to do more in order to hold things afloat. Honestly, the national team is under capacity as well... and so they are putting more onto sites. It's a pretty bad cycle that doesn't seem to be improving... and so more people continue to leave. I thought this was a norm within non-profits but that is not the case everywhere. The national team wants to build capacity at sites to do things on their own without national support but there isn't enough people at the sites to do it and their method of implementing this new model is poor.

review_title: No Leadership. No Culture. No Direction.
pros: The staff genuinely care about the students they work with.
cons:
The organization hasn't evolved since its founding. Back when it started, getting kids in the IT Help Desk pipeline was an incredible career opportunity, but now its not so much. Instead of solving this problem, and continually looking for new ways to make an impact, leadership spends all its time doing....? No one knows. But they certainly don't spend it being anything resembling transparent. 

The value proposition this org provides corporate partners also has faltered, leading to board members telling me directly they didn't see the value of the partnership outside of doing a good thing for underprivileged kids. All that said to me is we aren't preparing these kids for success. We're getting their hopes up so we can make a buck. 

Shady organization, folks. Steer clear.

pros:
The best reason to work here is to lose yourself in a full time ironic tragedy. Genesys Works Houston’s Season 17 of “The Office” is being directed by a disconnected, self-proclaimed best boss trying to convince corporate partners that leadership presides over a happy, well-run office. Meanwhile, student-facing staff are responsible for selling well-packaged empty dreams to high school interns. Assimilation training, demeaning work experiences, and manipulative relationships can be expected for most people of color, including students and staff. As long as you can Dwight your way to the top Willingly, Openly, Respectfully and Kindly, positions seem to open up for Wypipo to become Assistant to the Regional Manager. Coincidentally White I should say...

“Ah, humor. I have it too.” –Dwight
cons: The biggest downside of The Office is the foundational fabrication of “putting students first”. This Michael Scott prioritizes cooperate partners and donors regardless of how many students are sent to the warehouse. Please feel free to ask how they support their #FutureWorkforce after high school. Simply put, GWH claims to serve underserved communities but specializes in promoting overpriced, recycled White Savior Complex. Due to leadership oppressing and neglecting staff, ATLEAST 6 STAFF OF COLOR HAVE BEEN FORCED OUT OF THE ORGANIZATION SINCE JANUARY! If selling paper dreams to trusting teens isn’t enough of a con, you can definitely rely on making less than adequate pay to work overtime without support. For less than $38,000 a year, you can attend Scott’s Tots and Diversity Day.. every day!

review_title: Strangest and most toxic culture, of all time
pros: I’ve worked a lot of places. Flat out abusive places, bureaucratic places, collaborative places...this one tops the list with oddly incestuous and strange nepotism and insular, toxic culture from the top down. This organization purports to help youth, but actually uses the labor of low-income youth trying to support their parents and families to pad the pockets of their incompetent national managers. This organization is uniquely toxic in its inability to communicate, implement positive cultural change, or have any organizational effectiveness, as well as it’s very specific brand of micromanagement that is odd in the specificity of its level of inappropriateness. The kind of behavior and management technique senior leadership gets away with is the kind of behavior that spoiled and self centered celebrities who surround themselves only with people who agree with them and lavish them with praise  can compare to.
cons: The organization itself had an odd brand of mismanagement that unfortunately shows no signs whatsoever of improvement. This organization will likely run itself into the group by its shortsighted financial, organizational, and cultural practices, which include an unhealthy level of top-down criticism that is framed as positive feedback and self reflections, which is truly an expression of the overall nature and beliefs of the organization. If you fit in with the status quo and suck up to those above you, and keep your mouth shut, you’ll get paid. Not the greatest lesson to teach low income youth trying to keep a roof over their families heads, but a true one in many instances nonetheless.

review_title: Happy GW is in the Rear View
pros: Genesys Works has a solid mission that attracts some wonderful, socially conscious, anti-racist people to work with our city's youth. The program coordinators work EXTREMELY hard to provide a good experience to the students in the program and genuinely care about the work and the kids. I had an effective manager who I believe will be part of the solution for fixing this organization.
cons: The same thing cannot be said for the organization's leadership. They prioritize relationships with corporations over their staff and students to a shocking degree- often at the detriment of the student experience. Additionally its worth noting that though this organization serves 98-99% black and brown students, their leadership in the houston office is 100% white- not for a lack of extremely qualified black and brown employees that have come and gone over the years. Leadership is constantly trying to "do better" but I failed to see any real progress in the years I was there. Genesys Works had MANY opportunities to elevate the voices of their diverse staff but fell flat every time.

pros: Having just returned from an energizing all-employee retreat, I was again reminded how fortunate I am to be able to work with such a talented team of individuals all focused on helping to create positive change in the lives of the students we serve.  Genesys Works offers team members the opportunity to not only impact student lives, but the communities in which we live, and I'm proud to be a part of this terrific mission-driven organization.
cons: The Genesys Works model requires deep engagement with corporate partners in order to deliver the meaningful work experiences necessary to change the trajectory of life for the students we serve.  For those that appreciate and desire a more professional work environment balancing the best of what the nonprofit and business worlds have to offer, Genesys Works can be a great place to work.  But for those with a negative bias towards the corporate community in general and less interested in engaging with business partners for student benefit, it may not be the best career/culture fit.

review_title: Are the students best interest actually in mind?
pros: The experience that the students get is truly valuable- pushing students out of their comfort zone, gaining professional experience. There are also a lot of really great, well intentioned individuals that work for Genesys. The pay is competitive and benefits are good.
cons: It's tough working for an organization that is run by a national team that's both totally out of touch with the on-the-ground work and are also run by (mostly) all corporate men and their cronies. Honestly, the way I feel like leadership talks about the kids is gross, like they're the white knight saviors helping the poor brown kids and that's truly morally reprehensible. I'm honestly not sure Genesys Works will be around in a few years because of extreme mismanagement and disconnect. I'm also not sure the direction the organization wants to take has the students best interest in mind- it seems much more "how can we please and get money from our corporate partners."

review_title: Do Not Work Here - Stay Away
pros: The model is what the world needs. If the company was run correctly, it could change the country.
cons:
Staff are treated like dirt. Completely overworked to a point of loss of life balance completely, systemic low pay without improvement in sight (staff are considered low income in the cities they work in, that's how low the pay is), guilted when asking for raises or career development opportunities,  terminated without explanation, and worse, believe it or not. There is a HUGE amount of scapegoating, lying, and not taking responsibility for actions from senior leadership. I have never seen or heard of such a misrun company. 

Do not take a job here.

And if you're a young person looking to apply into this program, I'm so so so sorry to say, but find another program. The staff members, while brilliant and compassionate and warriors, are justifiably too preoccupied with protecting themselves from senior management, and senior management is too preoccupied with not knowing how to run a business and cleaning up all the messes they create.

job_title: Program Coordinator in Saint Paul, MN
pros: I am a person of color. I worked at Genesys Works twin cities for multiple year. The organization puts students first, but I wish Genesys Works would also put staff (other than leadership) as a top priority. Genesys Works-twin cities does put staff as a priority on paper, but I felt, rarely, did the organization do so in action. Hopefully things have improved; good luck with the search!
cons: As an entry level staff, I did not feel like I had much professional development or opportunities for growth.  I am a person of color. I worked at Genesys Works twin cities for multiple year.

pros: Connection with youth and opportunities to mentor
cons:
Terrible work culture. Many employees have left because of racist, misogynistic, xenophobic and overall abusive experiences with management and some peers. The only way to stay or be promoted (or paid decently) is to sell your soul, do things without critical thought or questioning, and to betray the mission and clients. 

GW is UTTERLY mismanaged and lacks a moral and ethical compass. This organization will do anything to please for money or recognition, even (or especially) if it means deserting the youth and employees' interests. If employees (past or current) have a good experience here, then I would seriously question their moral compass, and it would potentially be because of their skin color or gender (white or male).

Like others, I would be more worried and shocked if they were still around in the coming five or so years.\

pros: I have enjoyed my time working at Genesys Works. I think it is natural for people who have had either really negative or a really positive experiences to gravitate towards these review sites. But if we're honest the truth usually lies somewhere in the middle. And that has been what I found while working for this organization. During my time here I truly never felt mismanaged or undervalued. There were, and still are times where I feel overworked. But it is normal to have busy seasons in any job. We get the comfort of telecommuting once a week, and our schedules are flexible. The people this organization hires are incredible. David has also come in and made necessary changes and seems to have a great vision for where we are going.
cons: There are SO many initiatives, too many.

pros: The staff was really dedicated to students. Students were motivated and excited to earn wages while gaining important educational coaching.
cons:
Bureaucracy. So many little rules that made it hard to stay motivated. The ceo of national, Rafael, is also a liability. He makes strange comments to nearly everyone. 

The staff is nice but very cliquey. Most have been there a long time and really buy into the mission. Upper management imo looks down on students and doesn't understand why this work is even valuable. Overall mission is strange...it describes students as disadvantaged and poor, already placing them in a box. When given feedback, HR has not been helpful. The whole organization is resistant to change and growth.

pros: Local staff members at the sites are incredibly dedicated, talented and compassionate people.
cons: The division that has been created between the national office staff members and local sites continues to be exacerbated by a lack of transparency, greed, and misalignment between the on-the-ground work and national office priorities. There is a high usage of costly consulting services which sometimes seems to undermine the actual work of the organization.

pros: Helps disadvantaged students...not much else
cons: Genesys Works is extremely mismanaged. That includes both the National and Houston branches. A lot of the employees are overworked and expected to give up a lot of personal time. As an employee, you are expected to fit their mold quickly, and if not, you will be out the door. Expect to be micromanaged to the extreme. Everything you do will be scrutinized, and they will watch you like a hawk. Upper management is extremely accusatory. Expect to be yelled at and have your every word questioned. They will do anything to make themselves look good. It’s questionable whether management really even cares about helping disadvantaged students or is just in it for the money. Their entitlement really shows in the way they speak and carry themselves.

review_title: Great mission, but leadership lacking diversity and inequitable hiring/promotions
pros: GWH has a great mission and works with inspiring young people.  The organization has strong relationships with corporate clients in the Houston area and is able to offer valuable training and internship opportunities to students from underserved communities.  The organization attracts talented staff that are passionate about their work.
cons: The organization struggles with cultural competence nationally and at Genesys Works-Houston. As an organization that serves 98% students of color, this is an issue that really needs to be figured out soon. Inequitable hiring and promotions are clearly visible in the Houston office: lots of white people working in offices (leadership) and lots of staff of color working in the open office.  GWH does not offer a safe space for talking about issues of equity, which is one of the main reasons the problem continues.  Leadership tends to reward bubbly/upbeat personalities that keep their head down, while staff that ask questions and advocate for issues of cultural competence are tagged as problematic and get negative feedback from management (see previous review about "constant complainers").  The turnover for staff of color is significantly higher than for white staff, similarly the rate of promotions to management/leadership for white staff is higher than for staff of color.  Improving hiring/promotion practices is an issue leadership is now trying to address as the situation has become too plain to ignore.

pros:
I am a relatively new employee at Genesys Works and have been incredibly impressed by what I have experienced. 

First, the organization has a welcoming / service orientation to those who it serves and those within the organization. Every question was met with a  thoughtful answer and eagerness to get to know me better. From my very first day to the recent all staff retreat, there's no question that Genesys Works hires and fosters a culture of hard work and appreciation.

Second, the leadership has been transparent with its vision for Genesys Works and has engaged staff at all levels. It is nice to be a part of an organization that lives its values everyday in how it treats each other and shows tangibly how feedback is being used to inform decisions.

Finally, Genesys Works has given me the tools I need to be successful within my first 90 days and in the future. There are constant opportunities to gather feedback on performance, headquarters resources to help achieve my goals, and plenty of Genesys Works "gear" to show off my pride.

Having been a part of many organizations, I'm already impressed by what I see.
cons: It can be a challenge for Genesys Works, like any national organization, to maintain culture and connections between staff. I was excited to meet so many of my site / national counterparts and look forward to doing more of that in the future - particularly as we grow.

pros: I enjoyed mentoring and connecting with young professionals. I also enjoyed connecting with peers who had similar goals.
cons: I did not see enough professional development to keep me interested in the job after I mastered the role. The organization supports students from underrepresented communities, but the organization did not have many people of color when I left.

pros:
Some very sweet people work for this company.  It's a job.  The benefits are a paycheck and insurance.  I wish I could find more positive things to say, but I had a terrible experience at this company.
Great cause but not worth the abuse.
cons: Overworked and unhappy employees.  Strongly disapprove of the CEO.  No training.  No processes.  No documentation.  Very abusive environment.  Bullying.  I've never worked somewhere where so many women cry and are yelled at.

pros: Genesys Works helps high school students to get an internship with big companies and helps them what is like to experience in a top-level corporate environment either in accounting or Information technology( I did the IT position). Genesys Works helps prepare students not only their internship but with colleges too. They would train students over the summer and majority gets placed to a company that chooses the students.
cons: For the information technology track, I wish we learned more about coding.

pros:
Program staff is a team of talented, thoughtful, and innovative individuals with so much untapped potential. Program coordinators, managers, alumni team, and support staff create a supportive environment despite the toxic culture that exists. The program model is strong and has potential to be really great...maybe under better leadership or at a different organization. 

Lastly, students make the work worth it. The relationships with them are a constant reminder of why this work is important. So much respect for their work ethic and ability to succeed.
cons: Lack of Knowledge at the leadership level is detrimental to the well being of the Chicago site. The Executive Director is very underqualified for the role. It is very disappointing that a position like that is in the hands of someone with no nonprofit management experience or even adequate experience working with minority youth.  At times, comments were made about not ever having looked at nonprofit financials or not having any clue how to strategic planning works. As someone who takes those things seriously, it was hard to process those comments. There is a big disconnect with staff and no cultural competency of what students need.  Inequitable hiring/promotion undermines the idea that hard work, performance, and tenure leads to moving up. The environment is meant to lift people up to advocate for themselves and use their voices. But, an environment where people cannot speak up is being created. Staff turnover has been very high. People are leaving because of how toxic power dynamics are. Do better! Staff and students deserve more. Professional development is said to be a priority yet the staff is made to feel unqualified when they want to tackle new projects or have new ideas. How can your people grow in their careers, when the opportunities for them to lead projects are non-existent? Strategy seems to be misunderstood as well. Staff is exhausted, yet their concerns are not given proper weight. How can this site grow when the people power and institutional knowledge is quickly leaving? It is a reactive, not proactive culture.

pros: The mission is good, the students are greater. The organization has talented, inspiring staff who are passionate about the work they do. Pay is “non-profit” competitive for some positions.
cons:
The Bay, Chicago, Houston, and Twin Cities staff have brought up concerns regarding their leadership teams and been ignored to the detriment of staff morale and their sites in general. Examples can be seen here in the Glassdoor Reviews. Concerns about the Executive Directors (ED) of Bay Area (past), Chicago (past), and Houston (current) have been voiced consistently by PoC for years. 

White tends to be right at this organization, regardless of competency. White staff’s needs & careers are often prioritized over PoC (staff & students). Like many non-profits, the organization is whitest at the top with Black/Brown staff & students at the bottom. It’s not unheard of for EDs/leadership to attempt to dissuade PoC from applying to leadership roles. There have been a few calculated promotions of PoC but these, at times, are an obvious attempt to gain staff buy-in/quiet staff’s vocal concerns.

This organization can be unhealthy for anyone who doesn’t cater to leadership's egos. Organization-wide PoC (especially WoC) who challenge leadership or offer critical thought are labeled as negative, aggressive, and difficult to work with while white men are lauded for their ability to think outside the box. White men are free to raise their voices, cuss, throw tantrums, break the dress code, etc. while Black women are targeted and pulled into private meetings to discuss concerns regarding their facial expressions. 

PoC are encouraged to assume the best of their colleagues, but EDs/leadership assume the worst of PoC frequently. Staff are often asked to be solution-oriented but many times this is coded language for avoiding the true issues at hand in regards to internship quality, internship count, student experience/retention, staff experience/retention, alumni experience, school partner experience, white fragility, and white privilege.

review_title: Great organization making meaningful impact. An organization with unlimited potential to grow.
pros: Leadership trusts me to do my job and tries hard to communicate openly. One of the best non profits for competitive salary and benefits.
cons: Sometimes it is tempting to want to do additional work that’s outside of our mission and we need to just say no sometimes.

pros: Leadership is made up of sharp, smart and caring people. It is easy to respect them and their decisions. The culture is positive, upbeat, familial and caring. Everyone is working for the mission. Telecommuting and flex-time. Good health insurance. Great paid time off.
cons: There is a bit of turnover; I suspect some employees get experience and move onto larger or more well-known non-profits?

pros: The people who work here are all about the mission and will go above and beyond to improve their program. I never once felt like I wasn't support and apart of the team, even though I knew the IT Trainer job would only last for the summer
cons: I wish the position I had taken on was longer than 3 months

job_title: Business Technology Trainer in Champlin, MN
pros: Amazing coworkers, amazing students, lots of work but I had a lot of fun doing it! Its very rewarding seeing the young professionals learn the curriculum.
cons: I loved the job. Wish it had been for more then a two month temp position.

review_title: Company with dedicated staff to the mission
pros: Company has dedicated staff to the mission. Systems to implement program truly work.
cons: Need more support to implement infrastructure besides program. All sites have different processes and cultures, some better than others. Diversity of staff is an issue.

pros: GWBA is a social enterprise whose program makes a huge difference in the lives of it's students, partners and funders.  The program is measurable, impactful and celebrates diversity and youth.
cons: A shared vision is lacking and while the program is impactful, it may be too rigid to achieve scale in its communities

pros: Everyone always cares for your future. The Pcs will always be on top of you for any scholarships, FASFA, and the school you're going to. The job is pretty cool too, everybody is always friendly with you.
cons: They don't seem to pump up the wedge, it kinda low.

job_title: Program Coordinator in San Francisco, CA
pros: There was a healthy attitude around work culture and finishing at 5 o'clock.
cons: There's a lot of work expected year round and the role is consistently changing which makes it difficult to manage for a short-term position.

pros: Great place to work. Nice and fun people.
cons: They only have 3 months contract job for IT trainers in summer.

pros: Great job if you enjoy working with youth. You are able to make a meaningful impact on young professionals lives in a positive way.
cons: Hard decisions regarding young professionals are made often.

review_title: A great place to work, when they can afford it!
pros: It is a great organization with a great mission!
cons: Non-profits need to be lean, and when the pandemic of COVID-19 hit, there was a lot of layoffs

pros: The mission, the vision, my team
cons: National office management and communication

pros: Young Professionals (Students) are the heart and soul of this organization.   Does a great job staying on mission.
cons: Some departments are better than others

pros: Lots of great talent throughout this national organization
cons: Each market seems to have its own systems, need to streamline

pros:
- Mission Driven 
-Great Team
-  Opportunity for growth
cons:
- Lack of transparency in leadership 
- financial issues

review_title: Great place to work to help minority students
pros: There were great co-workers, and we got along pretty well.
cons: The directors were okay; not very diverse.

pros: Working with students and giving them viable opportunities to succeed
cons: Needs to build a workforce that can also reflect the students in the program

pros: Great people making a difference in breaking the cycle of poverty
cons: Challenging at times for organization to focus on being externally facing

pros: Friendly staff, great opportunity to work with youth and the community.
cons: Can be long hours at times.

pros: Prepare you for college and professional work environments.
cons: You have to work where they place you.

pros: Organization does great work with Chicago youth
cons: Senior staff and newer staff had a hard time connecting

pros: Very welcoming environment, great counselors,
cons: Downside is some people dont take advantage of intersnhip

job_title: Summer Program Assistant in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Friendly, inclusive, and hard-working staff. Great mission.
cons: No cons, love everything about the program.

pros: Really good learning experience
cons: A lot of pressure, but still manageable
